column4: audio is still not a friendly place in the Linux world. You might want to try killing the pulseaudio server.
...or start the application that doesn't work from the shell using "pasuspend nameofgame"
try pasuspend first, it helps with applications that can't talk to a sound server and will allow them to talk to the audio card directly.
hang on, let me see what package has that command.

packages.ubuntu.com claims it never heard of it, which is a lie. I deinstalled pulseaudio (because of an incompatible application that I use a lot), so I can't check locally, but I think it was in pulseaudio-utils
ah, correct, pulseaudio-utils it is, but the command is called "pasuspender" (note the "er" at the end).
find the command used to start your game, let's say /usr/games/mygame, then start it using "pasuspender /usr/games/mygame" and see if you got audio. If yes, great. If not, kick computer.
OpenAL is an audio library. Whatever that means. I bet it's related to not having... audio.
best case would be that the game is just missing a dependency (ie. a hint to automagically install a certain package). Then you would just have to find that package and install it.
best case: it installs something. worse case: it tells you the package is already installed and up-to-date.
excellent. If you want to spare others this pain, report "missing dependency for libopenal1" as a bug for the game.
somewhere around here: https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/ - but there's probably also a local Ubuntu command and someone can tell a bot to explain it to us.
no, enter as a command: ubuntu-bug alien-arena - and then answer a few questions.
